text: in this week's movies trouble with the
curve and of watch and how to survive a
plague the documentary how to survive a
plague is a story about the AIDS
coalition to unleash power this
aggressive gay activist organization
better known as act up was formed in New
York in 1987 in his review Stephen
Holden writes the film is a briskly
paced straightforward chronology made up
largely of footage shot mostly by the
protesters and told in their voices help
save her life their efforts were met
with indifference and hostility from
weary politicians the group collaborated
with pharmaceutical companies like Merck
in the development of new drugs
sophisticated pharmaceutical cocktails
have since made a is a chronic
manageable disease for those who can
afford the protocol the death rate
plummeted the success of act up might
serve as a template for other movements
like Occupy Wall Street whose protesters
also put their bodies on the line but
many of those protesters are not
fighting the personal immediate life or
death battles faced by members of act-up
who quite literally saved their own
lives
to deal with the AIDS epidemic and they
won't do it unless we force them end of

in his review AO Scott writes the movie
is easygoing and unsurprising Gus's
eyesight is failing and his job is
threatened by a younger front office
hotshot he may be ready for pasture if

Torino or any number of other
late-period
Eastwood movies you know that
